loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda S. is from the village of Pagalungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 50 years old. Rosalinda is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. She chose to have her loan decreased from 10,000 PHP to 5,000 PHP because she found it easy to make the payments.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosalinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ghulam Kubra's Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Kubra has applied for a loan to help her husband in his business of selling animals. Her husband handles two businesses: he sells animals and does labor work as well to earn an extra income. She is the mother of six children, who all are getting their education.

Ghulam Kubra is a very supportive lady. By taking care of her growing kids and husband, and by working hard, she shares the work burden with her husband. She helps him by raising up the animals for sale. Both parents work very hard to provide for the family.

Ghulam Kubra is hoping that with the help of this loan, her husband will be able to buy some more animals and earn a good profit when selling them.

loans.use: To purchase animals for resale.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz B., 62, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Iniego B., a vendor, they are blessed with a child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own meat shop for the past few years now.

Paz has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her meat business.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more meat to be incorporated into her current product inventory. She will be buying pork, poultry and beef.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and have more patrons.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more pork, poultry, and beef for her product inventory.

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en:
Zosima S. is from the village of West Poblacion, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Zosima is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Zosima owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Zosima has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Zosima joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zosima is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the Zosima's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita R., 40, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that she and her three children can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store while also selling breakfast fare during the mornings for the past few years.

Merlita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store and food business.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 20,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages for her variety store. She will also invest some of the loan in buying raw ingredients that she needs in order to continue selling breakfast food.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages for her variety store, as well as raw ingredients for her breakfast-fare business.

loans.name: Shahida Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Shahida Parveen is a resident of a city called Airfwala in Pakistan, where she lives with her husband and five children. Four of her children are getting their education and one is not yet of school-going age. Her husband is a fish merchant, while Shahida makes and sells mud utensils (pots) to help her husband financially.

Her husband wants to expand his business by purchasing more fish for his shop, and Shahida has applied for a loan to help him do this. With the help of the loan money, her husband will buy more fish, which will help him increase his income by fulfilling larger orders in time.

loans.use: Purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Kanizan's Group

texts.en:
Kanizan is a wife of M. A., living in a city named Arifwala, in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 15 years. She has given birth to six children: four sons and two daughters. All of her kids are enrolled in a local school and are getting an education. Kanizan is a caring and supportive lady. She manages the children's education expenses with her embroidery business.

Her husband has been a rickshaw driver for five years. In his years of experience, he has not been able to buy his own rickshaw because he was the only breadwinner of his family. But now his wife Kanizan helps him by making embroidered dresses on order.

Kanizan is applying for a loan from Asasah to purchase a rickshaw for her husband. By being the owner of his own rickshaw her husband will work more efficiently and earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase a rickshaw.

loans.name: Jhoan

texts.en:
Jhoan L. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old. Jhoan is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Jhoan owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Jhoan has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jhoan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jhoan is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Jhoan's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran is a wife of M. S., living in a city called Arifwala, in Pakistan. She is married with three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a milk seller and the younger is a vegetable seller by profession. Her daughter is just one year old.

Sugran is a very brave and happy-natured woman. She keeps a big smile on her face, which gives her family relief from their problems. She and her husband are involved in a bread-making business. They have an oven made of mud, which they heat with wood to bake bread. They sell each loaf for 5 PKR. They enjoy doing this work.

They have applied for a loan from Asasah to expand their business by buying flour in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase flour for their bread making and selling business.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin has been operating his retail business for the last three years. Previously he was working as a truck driver. The photo was taken at the main entrance of his shop. He sells retail in his community. The major challenge in his business is seasonality. Martin has another source of income from a side job driving commercial vehicles. He is a married man with a one year old child. He rents a house with electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and rent. 

With this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings, Martin wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and a sack of rice and to expand his business. Martin hopes that in future he will sell wholesale and cover a larger market. He decided to work with Yehu because of the accessibility to sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase three bundles of  wheat flour, maize flour and a sack of rice

loans.name: Jojean

texts.en: Jojean M. is from the village of Poblacion, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Jojean is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Jojean operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Jojean has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Jojean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jojean is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jojean from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Peena

texts.en:
Peena is a 39-year-old woman who lives with her husband and six children in an area called Gandheyan Autad. She is a very caring and supportive lady. She manages the domestic chores and helps her husband with his livestock business. 
 
Her husband L. A. is 55 year old. For the past 45 years, L. has been selling the milk produced by his buffaloes from his home. 

Peena is seeking a loan of 60000 Pakistan rupees to buy more buffaloes so that her husband can increase the amount of buffalo milk he produces. There is high demand for his buffalo milk, especially from his neighbors, who enjoy the taste and quality of his product. This is the second loan for Peena.

loans.use: Purchase more buffaloes to increase the milk-selling business

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie L. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 44 years old, married, and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $150 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hamidan

texts.en:
Hamidan is 54 years old and married with two daughters. She lives in an area called Gandheyan autad, which is situated in a city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the past twenty years. 

A very caring lady, Hamidan stays at home to manage the household chores and to take care of her family. Her husband belongs to an agricultural profession. He has experience working in the fields but he also handles a livestock business. He likes to take care of his buffalo and sells their milk. 

Hamidan’s brother also lives with her. He has completed his education to 10th standard, but couldn’t study further because he had to start work to support his family financially. He started helping his brother-in-law in his livestock business. Now he supports him by selling milk to neighbors and in the milk shops as well. 

Hamidan is applying for a loan from Asasah for her husband for the third time. With the loan amount he will buy more buffalo and increase the income from his business.

loans.use: Purchase more buffalo to increase the milk selling business

loans.name: Lila

texts.en:
Lila G. is from the village of Catohugan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $50 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Lila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem is a 28-year-old woman who lives with her husband in an area called Gandheyan autad, which is situated in a city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. She is not an educated lady but she hopes that if God blesses her with children, she will give them better opportunities for education so they can make their future bright and never face problems in their lives. She manages the domestic chores and helps her husband in his livestock business.  

Her husband, M. Hayat, is 28 years old. For the past six years he has been selling the milk produced by his buffalo from his home. This has become their family business because Naseem also helps him in getting and selling the milk. They enjoy working together. 

Naseem has applied for a loan for the first time from Asasah for her husband. With the amount he will buy another buffalo and expand their milk-selling business.

loans.use: Purchase buffalo for producing more milk to sell

loans.name: Ry

texts.en:
Mr. Ry P. was born in 1950. He is married and blessed with four children, three of whom are employed at different occupations, while another one attends school. 

Ry P. is engaged in his own business, the main operation of which is to buy and sell animals. He buys the animals in bulk from rural people and fattens them for a while before selling them. 

In addition, he owns a horse and a cart that he uses to provide taxi service, while his wife raises crops and pigs to earn a living. Ry P. is taking out his first loan to add to the financial capital of his animal trade. 

Ry P. was busy at his business activity when the photo taken, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To add to the financial capital of his animal trade.

loans.name: Rehana

texts.en:
Rehana is 33 years old and lives with her husband and four children in an area called Gandheyan autad, which is situated in a town called Kot Radha kishan and which is famous for its dairy business. This town is about 15 km from Riwind.  

Rehana's husband, L. A., is 31 years old. He is a very determined person. He not only takes care of their buffalo but he also sells their milk. He has knowledge of animal breeds, and is able to advise the people of his community. They come to him asking about taking care of their animals as well. He always welcomes them because he is very supportive towards his neighbors, and most of all because he is a good human being.
 
Rehana is applying for a loan for the first time from Asasah to invest the loan amount in their family business. With the loan they will buy another buffalo and expand their milk-selling business.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for their milk-selling business

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy P. is from the village of Lagunde, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a retail store, selling vegetables and different kinds of products for household needs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $300 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Cristy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
