loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena B., 52, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Manolito B., a driver, they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She distributes and retails gasoline to her neighbors and the surrounding community.

Lucena has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow twelve times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her fuel business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 17,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy wholesale fuel to be re-packaged in one-liter bottles and sold at retail prices.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fuel to be repackaged in one-liter bottles and sold at retail

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en: Estelita T. is from the village of Upper Cogon, Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 48 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Estelita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Estelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa M., 40, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Angelito M., a community worker, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Marissa has been managing her direct-selling business for the past few years. She sells clothing, cosmetics and footwear from the popular direct selling brands.

Marissa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her direct-selling business.

To ensure the success of her business, Marissa would like to apply for a PHP 32,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more advance orders for her customers.

Marissa dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She hopes that all of them will be able to finish their education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more advance orders for her customers

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith G. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Judith owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Tol

texts.en:
Mrs. Tol S., 26, sells various kinds of vegetables in a local market to earn a living. She buys the vegetables in bulk from farmers or wholesale suppliers and sells them retail to people who come to buy something for their cooking.

Tol S. is married to Hort Minea, age 30, who shares responsibility for his family by working as a military policeman. They are good parents to both their children who are students at the public school.

Tol S. is running her business well because she has skills in communication which she uses with her customers. However, her income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital.

Tol S. wishes to have more money to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To increase her business capital

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
Ma. Luisa L., 48, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Bernardino L., a civilian guard, and they are blessed with six children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Luisa manages her own variety store where she also sells commodities. She also rents out a few apartment rooms.

Luisa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow twelve times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Luisa would like to apply for a PHP 45,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying sacks of rice to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

Luisa dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally have her own stall for her business. She hopes to buy her own business space where she can maximize her income from all her businesses.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Natasha

texts.en:
Natasha is married and has a grown son. She lives in Mukachevo.

Natasha runs a small retail store called "Scarlett" located in downtown Mukachevo. In her little store she sells items such as purses, umbrellas, and wallets. She opened her retail store eight years ago. Her enterprise is popular among customers, as it has a favorable location and her merchandise is offered at affordable prices.

Natasha would like to receive a loan of 10,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventory. She works hard to balance her profits and expenses. The loan would remove the need for her to use money from her family budget to make purchases for her business.

loans.use: To increase her assortment

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim H. is a rattan basket maker. She is 58 years old and is a married mother, caring for three kids. One is a student and the other two are married and live away from home.

Since 2006, Kim H. and her husband have owned a small rattan basket production business. This couple also orders rattan items in bulk from other producers and takes them to sell door-to-door across the province. They always take a week or two weeks to sell their products.

Beside their current work, Kim H. and her husband always take time to cultivate rice crops for the dual purpose of eating and selling. The coming rainfall is good for growing but Kim H. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So she is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizer, insecticide, a water pump and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, insecticide, a water pump and seeds for planting

loans.name: Khin

texts.en:
Mr. Khin K. is 39 years old and is married with three children, one of whom works in construction.

Khin K. is a rattan furniture vendor. He sells furniture products that he orders from a wholesale supplier who lives near his village. His wife (shown in the photo above) stays at home to care for the children and to look after the house. She also makes rattan cupboards for a profit.

The family house is too old and small for them so Khin K. is looking for a loan to build a new wooden house to live in.

loans.use: To build a new wooden house to live in

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim K. has been spending her life cultivating crops since she was young. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent who died of senility year ago. Sim K. is now married and has two school-aged kids. Her husband frequently works alongside her in the farm fields.

Growing crops is an annual action with which Sim K. has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons.

The coming rainfall is good for growing but Sim K. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So she is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizer, insecticide, a water pump, and green bean seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, insecticide, a water pump, and green bean seeds for planting

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with a one small son. She lives in Korolyovo and sells bikes and spare parts at one of the local markets. She has been in this trade for five years.

Nataliya has passed many milestones on her road to success. Today she is a stable and confident entrepreneur with many bright ideas and plans for the future. 

Nataliya’s monthly income is 3,000 UAH. She would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase her inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and, as a result, increase her profits.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a Lebanese entrepreneur. He has been selling coffee from his trolley since 2000. Khaled is very well known in his region since he passes by all the streets and is very sociable. He likes talking to people and is very welcoming. Today, Khaled has chosen to take a loan of $1000 to purchase a juice machine for his work. Since the summer season is here, he wants to start offering juice to his clients. He hopes that this will allow him to increase his sales and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: To purchase a juice machine

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a married man of 36 years of age. He has owned a barber shop in his town since 1998. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building a network. He decided on doing this business to use his experience. He caters to a wide range of clients from the village and its neighborhoods. He is well known in the whole region and he always tries to be up-to-date with all the new cuts. 

Mohammad wants to purchase tools for his work and also to change the décor in his house. In order to do so, he is requesting $1,000 for the first time from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua. He hopes to enlarge his shop.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work and change the décor in his house

loans.name: Younes

texts.en:
Younes is a 30-year-old single man from Lebanon. He started working as a mechanic to earn an income to help with the many expenses of his family. Then, in 2004, Younes opened his own repair shop to improve his living conditions. He changes car oil and repairs tires and the wheel. 

Today, Younes is requesting a loan of $1,500 to purchase car oil for his garage. He hopes to keep on renewing his equipment and acquiring newer tools in order to develop and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase car oil for his garage

loans.name: Husein

texts.en:
Husein is a 28-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has owned a car repair garage since 2005. He is a specialist in repairing the bodies of cars. He repairs all types of cars. He decided on opening his garage because of his experience. When he first started, he had some financial issues. He is a hardworking man who does his best to improve his work. 

Today, Husein is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy new tools and purchase a scanner. He hopes to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To buy new tools and purchase a scanner

loans.name: Parsam

texts.en:
Upon returning from two years of service in the army, Parsam A. at the age of 24 found a means to make a living by opening a stationery store.  He rents a small shop in the city of Yerevan. Parsam is an economist due to his educational background and would like to put his skills to good use. He’s been running his business successfully for about two years. 

Parsam currently purchases the goods for his store from expensive sources. It would be much less costly and profitable if he could travel abroad to purchase the goods for his store. He is applying for a loan in order to travel and purchase large orders of goods at a lower cost in order to improve his business.

loans.use: Purchasing large orders of goods at a lower cost in order to improve the business

loans.name: Ayman

texts.en:
Ayman has been working as a farmer for the past 20 years. He's a 40 year old married man from Lebanon. He cultivates his land growing cherries, apples, prunes and peaches.

Today Ayman is requesting to borrow US $2,000 to purchase a beehive to raise bees. He hopes that his loan will allow him to improve and enlarge his work.

loans.use: To purchase beehive to raise bees.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 32 year old single man from Lebanon. In 2003, Mohammad opened a spare parts shop after his experience in this business. There is great demand for his spare parts thus he wants to buy more in order to fulfill his clients' requests.

He wants to take out a loan of $3,000 to buy more spare parts and enlarge his shop to meet his clients' needs and earn a good income for his family.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
BilA. is a Kiva borrower. He is a 27 year old married man from Lebanon who lives with his wife and their two young children. He has owned his own grocery store for the past year and is now asking to borrow $1,000 to buy a refrigerator and improve his store window to make it more attractive.

In his shop he sells candies, home cleaning products, dairy products, beverages, canned food, fruits and vegetables, and lots more. When BilA. opened his store a year ago, he had to face the competition in his region.  He decided on opening his shop because he wanted to have independent work.  His wife helps him in the store and sometimes she takes care of the store on her own when he has other commitments, so at least it’s a good compromise for both.

For the future, BilA. plans to keep on improving his store.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and improve his store window .

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Mariée et mère  de 6 enfants, Madame  Aminata Koné est âgée  de 37 ans. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec son mari, ses enfants  dans le quartier KoKo  de la préfecture de Koutiala  (Région de Sikasso).  
Elle n’ a pu faire d’études dû  à des raisons sociales. Alors elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus depuis son bas âge auprès de sa maman.  Après plusieurs activités, elle finit par opter pour la préparation du pâté de haricot appelé Fari. Elle exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans.  Elle est très bien sollicitée dans son secteur et appréciée à Koutiala.  
Pour  l’élargissement de son activité,  Madame Aminata n’a pas pris du temps à faire recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  depuis maintenant  2 ans.  Après avoir 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement sans difficulté, elle est à son deuxième prêt  individuel dont le précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce financement, elle compte acheter 10 sacs de haricot auprès des producteurs de céréales de Koutiala. Elle effectue ses ventes à domicile et dans le quartier  à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes, en détail et au comptant.   
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de  50.000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des  taux d’intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de sa famille. 
Avec ce financement sa perspective est bonne car elle doublera de bénéfice qui la permettrait d’améliorer sa condition de vie et bien mener son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs Aminata Koné is a 37-year-old mother of 6 living in a monogamous relationship with her husband in the Koko neighborhood of Koutiala prefecture (Sikasso region). She wasn't able to get an education for social reasons, so she learned about profit-making activities with her mother from a young age. After trying several businesses, she finally chose to prepare Fari, a bean pie. It has been her occupation for 15 years. She does good business and is very liked in Koutiala. In order to build her business, Mrs Koné didn't hesitate to call on the Soro Yiriwaso microlending institution, which she has been doing for 2 years now. After 3 group loans, all repaid without issues, she is now asking for her second individual loan, the first one having been repaid on time. With the money, she plans on buying 10 kidney beans bags from cereal producers in Koutiala. She sells from home and around the neighborhood, to women and men, for cash. She hopes for a 50,000 FCFA monthly benefit she will use to repay the Soro Yiriwaso interest rates and help with her family's daily purchases. This loan gives her good hope for the future as she will double her profit, which will allow her to improve her life conditions and her business.

Translated from French by Loïc Haméon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bags of kidney beans

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en:
Hiba is a Kiva borrower from Lebanon. She is a 44-year-old married woman who has six children. She has been running a grocery store since 1994. These stores are found in every neighborhood and village in Lebanon. 

When she first opened her store, she realized that it was a good location where she can attracts lots of clientele. Usually, her clients are her friends, neighbors and tourists. 

Hiba is requesting a loan of $2,000 from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, which she plans to use to increase her store’s inventory. This is her third loan from Al Majmoua. Her previous loans allowed her to continually improve her sales and increase her stock.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Abasse

texts.en:
Abasse is a 54-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He is married and has two children. Abasse has been running a tire garage since 1985. He sells and repairs all type of tires. He says that he is very committed to his work and proud of his experience. 

For the fourth time, he is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to purchase tires for his work. His previous loans allowed him to continually improve his work and purchase good quality products. He hopes to further expand his business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase tires for his work

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI 1  est issu de l’Association  de femmes mariées du village de Toura Nabitokan de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, 5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
AWA D. va utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI 1 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The BENKADI 1 group was created by the Married Women's Association of Toura Nabitokan village, in the San prefecture, Ségou region (fourth largest administrative region in Mali). These women live in traditional families, and on average are 34-year-old, have 5 children and farm peanuts. In the hope of making their farming profitable, the group's members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's lending program 3 years ago. They properly repaid their previous loans and are now requesting a third one. AWA D. will use her part of the loan to buy a sufficient amount of peanut seeds, small tools and fertilizer in the big Kimparana market. After winter, the crops are stored for some time until they gain value, after which they are sold in the Kimparana market and the surrounding markets, detail or wholesale, for cash, usually to client from the city. The BENKADI 1 group members plan on making a 35 000 FCFA profit each after the sale of their products and to use it to repay interests on the loan and their families usual expenses.

Translated from French by Loïc Haméon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizer, small tools and seeds

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 28-year-old married man from Lebanon. Since 2007, he has been working as a car painter in his town. Hasan decided on doing his business because of his experience. He is very famous in his town and known by his good reputation. He has a good number of clients who are people from his region. 

For the first time, Hasan requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase new tools for his work. He hopes to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his work

loans.name: Allah Malalyah Group

texts.en:
Saah J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Allah Malalyah". He is 36 years old and single. He was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to lack of support. For 2 years, he has been selling used leather belts in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He describes himself as jovial.

Saah J. plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollars (LRD) portion of this 32,000 LRD group loan to buy more used leather belts. His goal is to expand his business and open a store.

loans.use: To buy more used leather belts

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en: Moustafa is a 22 year old man from Lebanon. Since 2006, Moustafa has been working as a car seat repairer. His clients can be anyone from his region and its surroundings. For the first time, Moustafa is asking for a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua to purchase fabric to repair car seats. Moustafa is proud of his experience in this field of work. He hopes to keep improving his skills as well as his financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase fabric to use in the repair of car seats

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI I  est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Toura Nouakan dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, 6 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
MINATA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana, de Mororibila et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
MINATA D. tout comme les autres membres du groupe compte réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de la production agricole, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
BenkadiI 1 is a group of married women from the village of Toura Nouakan in the San Prefecture of the Segou region (4th administrative region of Mali) who live in traditional families. On average, the women are 30 years old and have at least six children. They grow peanuts. In order of turning a profit from their farms, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program three years ago. This is their third farming loan and they have repaid their previous loans. Minata D. will use her loan to buy peanut seeds, small agricultural tools and fertilizer, in the big Kimparana market. After winter, the crop will be stored for it to gain value and then sold at the Kimparana market and in surrounding markets, in stores (often in bulk), or to cash customers from large cities. The members of the group each expect to make a revenue of 35,000 CFA Francs from selling this agricultural product, which will be used to repay the loan and cover the family's expenditures.

Translated from French by Loïc Haméon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying seeds, fertilizer and small tools

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Toura Nabitokan dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans, 6 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
ADA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses  courantes  de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 2 is a group of married women from the village of Toura Nabitokan in the ex neighborhood of Kimparana in the district of San in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of the republic of Mali) who live in traditional families. They are on average 45 years old, with six children, and grow peanuts. In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of this group decided three years ago to become active in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having reimbursed previous loans, they are looking for a third loan. Ada D. plans to use her loan in order to purchase peanut seeds, materials and inputs from the large market of Kimparana. After winter, her products are stored for a certain amount of time in order to ensure they are valuable before being sold in the large market of Kimparana as well as in other markets nearby. They are often sold in large quantities to customers from other large cities. The members of the group hope to each realise a profit of 35 000 FCFA (approximately 67 USD) which they will use to reimburse the loans and interests on the loans and their family's expenses.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds, inputs and other materials

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées de l’association Benkadi du village de Toura Nouakan de la ville de SAN région de SEGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, 5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
KONIMBA FOUSSENI D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 2 is a group of married women from the village of Toura Nabitokan in the city of San in the Ségou region (4th largest administrative region of the republic of Mali) who live in traditional families. They are on average 37 years old, with five children, and grow peanuts. In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of this group decided three years ago to become active in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having reimbursed previous loans, they are looking for a third loan. Konimba Fousseni D. plans to use her loan in order to purchase peanut seeds, materials and inputs from the large market of Kimparana. After winter, her products are stored for a certain amount of time in order to ensure they are valuable before being sold in the large market of Kimparana as well as in other markets nearby. They are often sold in large quantities to customers from other large cities. The members of the group hope to each realise a profit of 30 000 FCFA (approximately 57 USD) which they will use to reimburse the loans and interests on the loans and their family's expenses.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds, inputs and small materials

loans.name: Minata

texts.fr:
Madame Minata Dembélé a 48 ans,  mariée  mère de  5 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Dû à des problèmes de famille, Aminata n’as pas pu continuer  ses études raisons pour laquelle elle s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus. Elle évolue dans le domaine du tricotage et de tissage de la  laine et sa vente depuis 15 ans. Elle   a appris cette activité  auprès des Sœurs Italiennes. Actuellement elle exerce à son domicile. Sa notoriété est bonne car elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes dans le  mois. 
Pour la bonne satisfaction de ses clients, Madame Minata n’a pris du temps pour rejoindre l’institution Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2005. Elle a obtenu 8 prêts solidaires (prêts de groupe) et 4 prêts individuels tous remboursés correctement. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Koutiala et compte acheter 3 cartons de laines auprès des commerçants. Elle vend ses layettes  dans la ville de Koutiala  et souvent dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants de Koutiala à une clientèle  constituée essentiellement de femmes, à crédit ou au comptant. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 80.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage  utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ms Minata Dembélé is 48 year old, married, and a mother of 5 children. She lives in a polygamous family in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye in the district of Koutiala (third largest adminsitration in the republic of Mali). Due to family problems, Minata was not able to continue her studies, and became interested in income generating activities. For the past 15 years she has been involved in knitting and weaving wool products, as well as selling them from her home. She learned this line of work through Italian nuns. She is well known for this activity, and receives several requests and order during each month. In order to better satisfy her customers, Ms Minata joined the Soro Yiriwaso institute in 2005. She obtained eight group loans and four individual loans, all of which she has reimbursed on time. She stocks up in Koutiala and plans to purchase three boxes of wool. She sells baby clothes in the city of Koutiala and often in the monthly fairs of surrrounding villages to a customer base mostly comprised of women. They pay either by credit or cash. She plans to make a profit of 80,000 FCFA (152 USD) per month which she plans to use to reimburse the interests on the loan as well as contribute to the family's daily expenses.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing boxes of wool

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Traoré est âgée de 48 ans mariée mère de 6 enfants. Elle  vit  dans une famille polygame avec son époux sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala  (région de Sikasso). 
Pour des raisons familiales, elle n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, raison pour laquelle elle s’est très vite intéressés aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle finit par choisir la vente de tissus et divers il y a 10 ans. Sa notoriété est bonne car elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes dans le mois.  
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle, en quantité et en qualité, elle décida de  faire recours à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 1 an. Après  2 prêts solidaires tous remboursés correctement,  elle est à son premier prêt  individuel.  
Avec ce  financement  elle compte acheter,  5 pièces  de tissus et divers à Lomé et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala au grand marché  de la ville, à une clientèle  composée de femmes et d’hommes,  au comptant ou a crédit.  
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des intérêts, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
Mme Oumou Traoré, 48, is married with six children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her co-wife and their children in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of Koutiala prefecture (Sikasso region). She never went to school, because very quickly she became interested in helping heer mother earn money. After trying several occupations without success, she ended up selling cloth and other goods ten years ago. Her reputation is good; each month she gets many orders. After having received two group loans, both fully repaid, she is now seeking her first individual loan. With this help she plans on buying five pieces of cloth and other goods in Lomé and will sell them in the big market in Koutiala, for cash or credit. She hopes to turn a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA to repay her loan, share in paying day-to-day family expenses, and invest in other money-making ventures.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cloth

loans.name: Obenikina 1 Group

texts.fr:
OBENIKINA 1  est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées du village de SAGINEKAN, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles ayant en moyenne 30 ans, 4 enfants et cultivant  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
KOROTOUMOU C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte  est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Obenikina 1 is a group of ten married women from the village of Saginekan in Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 34 and have four children, and they grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Korotoumou C. plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, she warehouses her harvest long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of the group hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ferftilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: Obenikina  2 Group

texts.fr:
OBENIKINA 2 est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées du village de SAGINEKAN de l’ex Cercle de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 49 ans, 4 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
MARIE D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Obenikina 2 is a group of ten married women from the village of Saginekan in the former San circle of Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 49 and have four children, and they grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Marie D. plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, she warehouses her harvest long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of the group hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: By fertilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: Obenikina 3 Group

texts.fr:
OBENIKINA 3  est un regroupement  de femmes mariées du village de SAGINEKAN dans la sous préfecture de KIMPARAMA région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 4 enfants. Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
NAPOUCHO D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes  de la famille.
texts.en:
Obenikina 3 is a group of married women from the village of Saginekan in Kimparana sub-precture in Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 35. Each has at least four children. They grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Napoucho D. plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, the harvest will be warehoused long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of the group hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy N. S. is married with three children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a businessman and he contributes to the family's  basic needs. Dorothy has been operating her retail shop for the last five years.She sells retail to her local customers. Her other sources of income are from rental houses and the selling of firewood. Dorothy faces major challenges of theft and high transport costs. She owns a home with no electricity or piped water. She would like to save enough money to allow her children have a good education. To do that Dorothy is asking for a loan of Kshs 60,000 to start a motorcycle business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Obenikina  4 Group

texts.fr:
OBENIKINA  4  est un groupe de femmes mariées du village de SAGINEKAN de la ville de KIMPARAMA région de SEGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans et au moins 4 enfants. Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
MAIMOUNA S. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,   au grand marché de Kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte sera stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses  courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Obenikina 4 is a group of married women from the village of Saginekan near the town of Kimparana in Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 36. Each has at least four children. They grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Maimouna S. plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, she will warehouse her harvest long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of the group hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working capital to purchase a greater variety of fruits

loans.name: Valerio

texts.es:
El señor Valerio Fernández P. tiene 27 años de edad y vive en el barrio Simón Bolívar de la ciudad de Tarija. Valerio aun no se caso y vive en casa de sus padres. Valerio se dedica  al servicio de transporte de áridos (arena, ripio, grava, piedra, etc.) el cual vende en las diferentes construcciones que hay en la ciudad, actividad que viene realizando desde hace muchísimos años. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                 Valerio quisiera formar una familia, tener hijos y en un futuro nietos, el nos cuenta que tiene la necesidad de comprar material de construcción para su casita, el crédito será destinado para la compra de dicho material.       
                                                                                                                                                                Valerio nos cuenta que el próximo crédito que solicite será para mejorar las condiciones de su casa.
texts.en:
Mr. Valerio F. P. is 27 years old and lives in the neighborhood Simon Bolivar in the city of Tarija. Valerio has not yet married and lives in his parents' house. He makes a living by transporting materials such as sand, gravel, and stone, which he sells to various construction companies in the city, an activity that he has been doing for many years. Valerio would like to form a family, have children, and grandchildren in the future. He tells us that he needs to purchase construction material for his house, which is why he is requesting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction material for his home

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius S. M. is a married man with three children. One attends school, while the others  are still too young for school. Julius owns a house with no electricity or piped water. He has been operating his carpentry business for the last six years and sells in a shop to social services workers and teachers. He operates a motorcycle business as his other source of livelihood.

Julius is asking for a loan of Kshs 40,000  to purchase twenty pieces of timber.  He faces the challenge of the high cost of transportation and seasonality. Julius hopes that someday he will have an electric planing machine.

loans.use: To purchase twenty pieces of timber.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
El Señor Juan Carlos P. C. de  26 años de edad, es soltero y trabaja para mantener a su persona ya que él no tiene familia ni esposa, sus padres fallecieron  cuando el tenia 18 años y desde entonces él se dedica al trabajo.

Juan Carlos P. C. es un joven muy dedicado a su trabajo, el trabaja en el sindicato de transportistas de  moto taxis 2 de Agosto donde trabajo con una motocicleta que no es suya para subsistir en este mundo. 

El señor Juan Carlos P. C. se apersono a las oficinas en busca de un crédito para un reintegro para la compra de una motocicleta para así poder tener su propia herramienta de trabajo y así poder ahorrar dinero para que en un futuro pueda formar su hogar y una familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan Carlos P. C. is 26, single and works to support himself since he has no wife nor children. His parents died when he was 18 and since that time he has been working. He is a young man who is dedicated to his work. He is in the August 2nd moto taxis union but he uses a machine that isn't his since he needs to survive in this life. Mr. Juan Carlos P. C. went to the offices himself to request a loan to be able to purchase a mototaxi. He wanted to own one himself so that he could save money and in the future have a home and family.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to be able to buy a mototaxi

loans.name: Ruben

texts.es:
El Señor Ruben C. G. es soltero y trabaja para mantener a su familia, su madre y sus dos hermanas menores ya que su padre se separo de su lado  cuando el tenia 18 años y desde entonces él se hace cargo de su familia.

Ruben C. G. es una persona  muy dedicada a su trabajo, el trabaja en el sindicato de moto taxis “CARRASCO” que es el único ingreso familiar que tiene, el trabaja como chofer ya que el no cuenta con una motocicleta por lo cual genera un ingreso para mantener y ayudar a su familia y sus hermanos.

El señor Ruben C. G. a las oficinas en busca de un crédito para la de una Motocicleta para así poder así contar con una herramienta propia y así poder tener más ingresos para el bienestar de madre y sus hermanas y un futuro y bienestar  mejor para su familia.
texts.en:
Ruben C. G. is single, and works to support his family, his mother, and two younger sisters. His father left the family when he was 18 years old, and since that time he has taken on this responsibility. Ruben C. G. is a hard worker, working for the Carrasco motorcycle taxi union, which is the only family income he has. He works as a driver because he doesn’t own a motorcycle, and this way generates income to support and help his family and his siblings. Ruben C. G. came to the office in search of a loan to purchase a motorcycle, and thus have his own means to generate more income for the wellbeing of his mother and sisters, and a better living and future for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for taxi service

loans.name: Alejandra Elizabth

texts.es:
Alejandra de 43 años, vive en el suburbio de Guayaquil (zona urbana, la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes informales), Ella vende productos de uso personal Yambal (empresa que ayuda a mujeres a trabajar con productos por catalogo a un bajo costo).   

Para poder ayudar a su esposo económicamente ella empezó a vender productos de uso personal a sus vecinos y conocidos, poco a poco durante estos años a tenido clientela suficiente para ganar dinero. Ella trabaja en distintos horarios vendiendo perfumes, cremas y cosméticos. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar perfumes, cosméticos y ropa para la venta. En el futuro quiere construir mejor su casa.
texts.en:
Alejandra is 43 years old and lives in the suburbs of Guayaquil (an urban area where the majority of the inhabitants are merchants). She sells personal products through Yambal, a company that helps women work with catalogue products at a low cost. In order to be able to help her husband economically, she began to sell products to her neighbors and acquaintances. Little by little, over the years she has maintained a sufficient clientele to earn money. She works different schedules, selling perfume, creams, and cosmetics. With this loan, she wants to purchase perfume, cosmetics, and clothing to sell. In the future she would like to make improvements to her house.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase perfumes, creams, and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Erasmo

texts.es:
El Señor Erasmo J. Cáceres de 21 años de edad, es soltero y trabaja para mantener a su familia, su madre y sus 3 hermanos menores ya que su padre los abandono cuando el tenia sus 18 años y desde entonces él se hace cargo de su familia.

El es un joven muy dedicado a su trabajo, trabaja como moto taxista en el sindicato CARRASCO en el cual ya va trabajando más de dos años, el cliente lleva diariamente para el sustento de su madre y sus hermanos  para que en un futuro ellos tengan y gocen de las comodidades de las que él no gozo en su juventud.

El señor Erasmo se apersono a las oficinas en busca de un crédito para un reintegro para la compra de una Motocicleta para así poder trabajar en la localidad de ivirgarzama ya con herramientas propia así poder tener más ingresos para el bienestar de su madre y sus hermanos y un futuro mejor para su familia.
texts.en:
Erasmo J. Cáceres, 21, is single and works to take care of his family, his mother and his three younger siblings since his father abandoned them when Erasmo was 18. Since then he has been responsible for his family. He is a young man who is very dedicated to his work. He works as a moto taxi driver with CARRASCO, where he has been working more than two years. He transports customers daily so he can take care of his mother and siblings so in the future they will have and enjoy the things he didn't have in his youth. Erasmo came to the offices looking for a loan to buy a motorcycle so he can work in the town of Ivirgarzama with his own equipment and have more income for the well-being of his mother and siblings and for a better future for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of motorcycle for taxi service

loans.name: Bertoli

texts.es: Bertoli L. Q., tiene la edad de 53 años, es soltero y vive solo. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de pescado para su venta.  La idea es comprar variedad de tipos de pescado y así poder venderlo a un precio mayor y obtener una ganancia. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Bertoli tiene algunos años en este negocio y espera aumentar sus ventas y seguir creciendo como comerciante. El espera en un futuro mejorar su calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como comerciante.
texts.en:
Bertoli L. Q. is 53 years old, single, and lives by himself. He is requesting this loan to buy fish to sell. The idea is to buy a variety of types of fish, so he can sell them at a better price and make a profit. This is the first time he is taking out a loan from FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the services they offer. Mr. Bertoli has been working in this business for several years and he hopes to increase his sales and to keep growing as a businessman. He dreams of a better future, with a higher quality of life and greater economic stability, and he would like to continue to grow as a person and as a businessman.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a variety of fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Building materials

loans.name: Olidier

texts.es: Olidier V. S., tiene la edad de 29 años, está en unión libre, y tiene un hijo de 3 años que es  su mayor prioridad.  El crédito lo quiere para la compra de cerdos para la cría y engorde. La idea es darle el adecuado mantenimiento a los cerdos para poder desarrollar animales de mejor calidad, y obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando se vendan. El desea aprovechar  las instalaciones que posee para desarrollar la actividad de los cerdos. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Olidier  tiene varios años en este negocio de cerdos. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Olidier V. S. is 29 years old. He is single and has one three year old son who is his top priority. He is asking for this loan in order to buy hogs to raise and fatten up. He wants to give them adequate care in order to develop better quality animals, so that he can obtain the greatest amount of income possible when he sells them. He wants to take advantage of the pens he has to raise the hogs. This will be his first loan through FUDECOSUR and he is pleased with the ease through which he was able to obtain it. Mr. Olidier has been running this hog business for several years and wants to be able to provide his family with a better quality of life, give them economic stability, and continue to grow as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hogs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a taxi

loans.name: Gaitan Group

texts.es:
El grupo G. lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es la señora Martha Rosa L. Chavarría quien tiene una tortillería. Ella inicio según comento  por sugerencia de su hermano quien la ánimo a crear su propio  negocio hace seis años. Es así que compro un cuartillo de maíz que es la mitad de un medio en la actualidad L. compra medio quintal de este producto.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son María Asunción B. G. quien hace 28 años inicio a realizar tortillas y sopas y Fátima de los Reyes G. García tiene una pequeña pulpería hace cinco años.
texts.en:
The G. Group consists of three hardworking women. One of them is Sra. Martha Rosa L. Chavarría who has a tortilla shop. She started this business six years ago upon the suggestion of her brother who encouraged her to engage in this venture. At first she bought a fourth of a quintal (1 quintal = 46kg) of corn, but now she needs to buy half a quintal for her business.

The other members of this group are María Asunción B. G., who has been selling tortillas and soups for 28 years, and Fátima de los Reyes G. García, who has managed a small grocery store for five years.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for making tortillas

loans.name: Santo

texts.es:
El Señor Santo F. R., es una persona que se dedica a trabajos en construcción (albañil) está casado y trabaja para el bienestar de su familia.

El señor Santo F. R. trabaja como maestro albañil dia tras dia tiene la esperanza de contar con herramientas propias para así poder trabajar con sus propias herramientas, el ya hace como unos 10 años que trabaja como albañil para poder apoyar y mantener su familia. 

El señor Santo F. R. se apersono a las oficinas en busca de un crédito para la compra de una mescladora de cemento para facilitar su trabajo y así poder tener más ingresos para el bienestar de su esposa, sus hijos y facilitar un futuro mejor para su familia.
texts.en:
Sr. Santo F. R. is an individual who works in construction as a mason. He is married and works for the well-being of his family.

Sr. Santo is a master stonemason who day after day hopes to be able to work with his own equipment. He started his job ten years ago in order to support and sustain his family.

Sr. Santo visited the CIDRE offices to apply for a loan so that he could purchase a cement mixer to facilitate his work. This will allow him to earn more income for the welfare of his wife, his children, and help establish a better future for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cement mixer

loans.name: Gonzalo Benigno

texts.es:
Gonzalo de 45 años, vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana, llamada así porque en su antigüedad la flor orquídeas era la mas común). Antes de tener la tienda el tuvo que aforzarse mucho para tenerla, haciendo ventas de legumbre y frutas afuera de su casa con una mesa. 

Poco a poco fue aumentando su negocio y pudo construir su casa para tener su tienda junto a donde vive. Ahora tiene su tienda mas surtida, vende enlatados, granos, bebidas etc. El espera comprar con el préstamo arroz, legumbres para seguir vendiendo en su tienda. En el futuro quiere tener su propio minimarket.
texts.en:
Gonzalo is 45 years old and lives in Las Orquídeas in Guayaquil (an urban area that is named after the orchids that were common in ancient times). Prior to having his store, he had to work extremely hard to obtain it. He sold legumes and fruits from a table outside of his home.

Little by little, Gonzalo was able to expand his business and eventually build a house where he could live and open a store. He now has a store that is well-stocked with canned goods, grains, beverages, and other products to sell. With this loan he plans to buy rice and legumes to keep his store running. In the future he wants to have his own mini-market.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice & legumes

loans.name: Norma Magnoly

texts.es:
La señora Norma Magnoly R. A. llego el año 1999  del Beni  junto a  su familia,  a puerto Villarroel en Cochabamba con la esperanza  de buscar mayores oportunidades de vida, en los primeros  años norma trabajo junto a su madre vendiendo comida camba, y así poder costear sus estudios de colegio, porque no alcanzaba sus ingresos que ganaban sus padres, puesto que son  siete hermanos.

Posteriormente concluido sus estudios de colegio trabajo en el hospital, y actualmente  trabaja en la institución PRODEM como cajera, al mismo tiempo quiere reactivar su puesto de venta de empanadas es para esto que está pidiendo el crédito ella desea reabrir su puesto de comida y así poder tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Sra. Norma Magnoly R. A. came from Beni with her family and arrived in 1999 in the outlying community of Villarroel in Cochabamba with hopes of finding better opportunities. During the first few years she was here, Norma worked with her mother selling local dishes to help pay for her high school studies. Her parents did not earn enough money since they had to support seven other children.

Norma worked at a hospital after she finished high school. She currently works as a cashier at an institution called PRODEM. At the same time, she wants to reopen her food stall so that she can begin selling turnovers. For this reason, she is requesting a loan so that she can restart her food business and generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to reopen her food business

loans.name: Los Canastitos Group

texts.es:
El grupo los Canastitos está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras, decididas y emprendedoras provenientes de Masaya considera la cuna del Folklor nicaragüense. Este departamento cuenta con la mayor expresión Folklórica y una gran variedad de producción de arte y artesanía. 

La coordinadora del grupo es María de los Ángeles D. Castillo propietaria de un pequeño taller donde realiza ropa típica como cotonas, blusas, maxi, guayaberas…etc. Ella inicio hace cinco años realizando unos cuantos productos en la actualidad tiene tres colaboradores y sus dos hijos quienes le ayudan.  D. invertirá el préstamo en materia prima en especial telas e hilos para seguir progresando. 

Las otras integrantes del grupo son Teresa del Carmen R. S. quien realiza fundas, sabanas y ropa para bebes y Rosa T. se dedica al comercio de platanitos y enchiladas.
texts.en:
The Canastitos Group is made up of three hard-working, determined, and enterprising women from Masaya, a region considered to be the cradle of Nicaraguan folklore. The department of Masaya is known for having the greatest expression of traditional Nicaraguan arts, and for producing a great variety of arts and handicrafts. The coordinator of this group is María de los Ángeles D. Castillo, who owns a small sewing workshop where she makes typical clothing items like cotton coats, blouses, long dresses, guayaberas [short-sleeve, button-down shirts for men], etc. She started this business five years ago, making just a few products. Now, she has three employees as well as her two children helping her. D. will invest this loan in buying materials, especially fabrics and thread, so that she can keep progressing in her business. The other members of the group are Teresa del Carmen R. S., who makes slipcovers, sheets, and baby clothing, and Rosa T., who sells plantains and enchiladas.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread

loans.name: Obenikina 5 Group

texts.fr:
OBENIKINA 5  est un  regroupement  de femmes mariées du village de SAGINEKAN de la sous préfecture e KIMPARAMA région de SEGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et au moins 4 enfants. Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
SABINE S. souhaite utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les  dépenses  courantes  de la famille.
texts.en:
OBENIKINA 5 is a group of married women from the village of Saginekan, in the sub-prefecture of Kimparama, Region of Segou, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families. They are an average of 34 years old and have at least four children. They grow peanuts. In hopes of making their agricultural work more profitable, the members of the group decided to participate in the loan programs of Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After having properly repaid their previous loans, they are on their third business loan. Sabine S. hopes to use her loan to buy adequate quantities of peanut seeds, small equipment, and fertilizers at the main market in the city of Kimparana. After the winter season, the crops are stored for a period of time so that they will increase in value before being sold at the main market in Kimparana and in neighboring markets at retail (and often wholesale), for cash, generally to clients from large cities. The members of the group expect to earn, after the sale of their agricultural products, a profit of 35,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loans and to meet daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Tiessiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
TIESSIRI 1  est un groupe  de femmes mariées du village de NITOLOSSO dans le la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, 4 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
SALIMATA D. espère utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Tiessiri 1 is a group of married women from the village of Nitolosso in San prefecture, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional extended families. On average, they are 30 and have four children, and they grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Salimata D. plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, she warehouses her harvest long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of the group hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: Tiessiri 2 Group

texts.fr:

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Las Manzanas Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Manzanas está integrado por Catalina P., Emelina P. y  Rolando José ellos son provenientes de Masaya. La coordinadora del grupo es la señora P. quien desde hace 30 años se dedica a realizar sopas y  arroz de leche. En la actualidad desea introducirse en el destace de cerdo, ya que este le generaría mayores ganancias es por ello que con el préstamo piensa comprar cerdo y materia prima.

Mientras Emelina P. realiza tortillas y nacatamales desde hace tres años y Rolando José P.  es comerciante de frutas desde hace dos años.
texts.en:
The Las Manzanas ("The Apples") Group is made up of Catalina P., Emelina P., and Rolando José, who are all from Masaya. The group's coordinator is Ms. P., who has been making soups and rice pudding for the last 30 years. Now, she hopes to get started in the business of butchering pigs, as this would create more income. With this loan, she plans to buy pigs and raw materials. The other group members are Emelina P., who has worked for the last three years making tortillas and nacatamales [a food that is similar to tamales, made of corn and meat steamed in banana leaves], and Rolando José P., who has been a fruit-seller for two years.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs, vegetables, meat, bone, rice, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Tiessiri  3 Group

texts.fr:
TIESSIRI 3 est un groupe de femmes mariées du village de NITOLOSSO dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, 4 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
KADIA C., la présidente du groupe,  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte  est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Tandis que KADIA C. espère avoir 40.000FCFA de bénéfice, les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Tiessiri 3 is a group of married women from the village of Nitolosso, San prefecture, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 30 and have four children, and they grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Kadia C., the group's president, plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, she warehouses her harvest long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. Kadia C. plans on making a 40,000 CFA profit, while the other group members hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each after their produce is sold, to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: María

texts.es: María, D. 55 años D. edad, es divorciada y tiene cuatro hijos, dos D. ellos son independientes y el resto están en etapa escolar. Juntos residen en L. localidad D. Quimbiri, ubicada en L. ceja D. L. selva peruana, donD. tienen su propia casa. María, recuerda que empezó con su negocio que es un Bar – Recreo, contando con tres mesas y  ocho sillas, al inicio le fue difícil ya que los gastos eran más que lo ingresos, pero con el tiempo y con L. fuerza emprendedora que le caracteriza, su negocio fue creciendo D. manera lenta pero segura. Hoy su negocio es muy conocido en su localidad, en donD. recibe a sus clientes mas asiduos, el factor clave radica en el buen servicio que otorga, así como también D. las bebidas exóticas que ofrece, en ocasiones realiza fiestas D. promoción, cumpleaños, o cualquier otro evento, ya que su local está diseñado para ese tipo D. fiestas. En su trabajo tiene a cargo D. dos señoritas para que L. ayuden en L. atención D. los clientes y lo realizan D. manera eficiente y eficaz. Su horario D. atención es a partir D. las 10:00 D. L. mañana hasta las 3:00 D. L. mañana del día siguiente, es por ello que se siente contenta con su trabajo, ya que esta obteniendo buenos resultados económicos, sin embargo, con el tiempo espera tener su propia tienda D. venta D. ropa, con L. finalidad D. diversificar su negocio. Este es su decimoctavo crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con su cronograma D. pagos, además está satisfecha por el buen trabajo D. su grupo comunal. Con el crédito que solicita, lo piensa invertir en darle un mejoramiento a su Bar-Recreo, adquiriendo mesas, sillas, artesanías D. L. zona, cuadros, para darle un estilo innovador y acogedor en su negocio.
texts.en:
María, 55, is divorced and has four children. Two of her children are now independent and the rest are school-aged. They live together in their own house in the town of Quimbiri, located on the edge of the Peruvian rainforest. María notes that she started her own business, which is a bar/recreation space that has three tables and eight chairs. At first, it was difficult because her expenses were greater than her income. However, with time and thanks to the entrepreneurial strength that characterizes her, María's business grew slowly but surely.
