*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Ang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ang C. is 46 years old and is the village bank president.  She has been selected by its eighteen members who are located in Kantout Thom village in Takeo province. Each member will use their loan for their individual businesses.

Mrs. Ang C. and her husband, Mr. Sorn Saem, are farmers who own two hectares of land on which they cultivate rice for a living. Aside from being farmers, Mrs. Ang C. is a pig breeder at home and her husband is a vegetable seller in the local market. With both businesses they are able to earn a small income to support their family. To expand both businesses, Mrs. Ang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding, and to buy more vegetable to support her husband's business. This couple has eight children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a vegetable seller, and the other five children are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying produce to sell

loans.name: Tsedevsuren

texts.en:
Tsedevsuren D. is 27 years old and lives with his wife and 2-year-old son in Uvurhangai province, central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. 


Tsedevsuren operates a cellphone sales and repair service from a rented stall at his local market. He started his business in 2006 after completing a cellphone parts and repair training course. He has made much progress over the last year and has built up a strong customer base. Tsedevsuren has gained much experience operating his business and continues to improve his phone repair skills. The success of his business has encouraged him to expand and he dreams of, one day, owning his own repair shop. 


He is requesting a 1,900,000 MNT loan to purchase cellphones and cellphone parts to increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Neang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Neang C. is 34 years old and the village bank president. She was selected by the 16 members who are located in Pongro village in Takeo province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose and they hope to increase their income to improve their family's living conditions.
 
Mrs. Neang C. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, she is also a pig breeder at home. She earns a small income to support her family. In order to support the farm, Mrs. Neang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds and fertilizer and to pay a laborer to plow her farm. texts.en:
Mrs. Bet E. is a 54-year-old married woman who lives in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. 


She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. Bet E.'s husband works with her in the farming business. They have three kids. One of her children is married and the other ones are single.


The coming rainfall makes it feasible for Bet E. to plant crops, however, she doesn’t have the capital for this. Thus, Bet E. is looking for a loan to buy fertilizers, insecticides and seeds.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, insecticides and seeds

loans.name: Rosela Empas' Group

texts.en: Mrs. Rosela E. is from the barangay (neighborhood or district) of D. Fernan, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years of age. She is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by PMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosela E.’ Group. Rosela is married and blessed with four children, all of whom are now at school age. For her source of income, she is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari store (variety or general store) business. Aside from that, she is also receiving support from her husband, who is a farmer. Their main source of income comes from their sari-sari store and they earn approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for eight years already. In 2010, Rosela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As an active member of the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities, she is now requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital for her sari-sari store business. This will be the second loan taken out by Rosela from PMPC. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of her family, as loan repayments and as savings for the future education of her children. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Jurynda

texts.en:
Jurynda R. is from the village of Libertad, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 32 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $225 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jurynda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Cheang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheang K., 63 years old, is the village bank president selected by the eight members of a village group loan located in Ta Pov village, Takeo province. The members of this group loan hope to increase their income to improve their families' standard of living.

Mrs. Cheang K. is a farmer who works very hard to support her two children. To improve her farm, Mrs. Cheang K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to cultivate rice, corn and beans. Her husband is a village chief and also helps his wife with the farming. This couple has two children: one is a farmer and one is a student in the local school.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Mrs. Nov S. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of about $2 per day. Her husband earns a living by working in the construction field. He is hired by people to build their new houses, a skill he learned from his grandparents. This couple has been married for years and has a single child who is employed. 

Nov S. sees that her husband travels to his work location by paying for a taxi at a high price. Nov S. hopes to reduce this expense by asking for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her husband's use.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. M. is a middle-aged woman whose husband is shown in the photo. M. has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than four years. She sells fish that she gets from her wholesale supplier and from fishermen.

M. is married to Sun Ngoeun, 52, who works as a military policeman in the Ministry of the Interior. The couple has four school-aged kids.

M. is running her fish-selling business smoothly because she has skills in communication which she uses with her customers. However, her income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient capital. She wishes to have more money to add to her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan of $400.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

Crispina is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Crispina owns and operates a specialized retail store. Crispina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Crispina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Vanna's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna K. is 48 years old and the village bank president. She was selected by the 11 members who are located in Pongro village, Takeo province. Each of the members of this village loan will use the loan for a different purpose. 
  
Mrs. Vanna K. and her husband, Mr. Dam Nuth, are farmers who own two hectares of land to cultivate rice. They are farmers who work very hard to support their family. With the loan, Mrs. Vanna K. wants to buy rice seed and fertilizer, and to pay a laborer to support her crop. Aside from farming, Mr. Dam Nuth is a fisherman who earns a small income to support his family. This couple has two children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other one attends a local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer and to pay a laborer

loans.name: Ham

texts.en:
Mrs. Ham H. is 56 years old and is a widowed mother devoted to her two children. One is now married and lives separately while the other one is single.

Ham H. stays at home to manage the family housework as well as selling some inventory to the villagers. She sells items such as cooking equipment, soft drinks, snack food, sweets (candies), meat, and some vegetables. She buys her items in bulk on credit from wholesale suppliers and pays when she sells all her products.

Ham H. thinks that it is time to sustain her business’s growth and look for extra revenue, which she proposes to do by increasing her inventory. Due to the fact that she doesn’t have capital to make that possible, she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of inventory
